sect1.title: OpenJDK-&openjdk-version;

sect2.title: Installation de OpenJDK
sect2.para: The instructions below install both the binary et source versions. You may stop after installing the binary version or continue on installing the source version. You can choose to keep either or both.
Begin by extracting the appropriate binary tarball et changing to the extracted dirctory. Install the binary OpenJDK with the following commands as the root user:
Configure the temporary OpenJDK installation with the following

screen.userinput: export PATH_HOLD="${PATH}" && export JAVA_HOME="/opt/OpenJDK-&openjdk-version;-bin" && export CLASSPATH=".:/usr/share/java" && export PATH="${PATH}:${JAVA_HOME}/bin"

sect2.para: The binary version is now installed. If you don't want to compile the sources, skip ahead to the configuration section.

note.para: The source build of OpenJDK requires . You'll need to build that first to satisfy the reciprocal dependency, et return to this section to continue building OpenJDK.

sect2.para: Unlike other packages in BLFS, the OpenJDK source packages are distributed in multiple downloads. Since the IcedTea build harness wil be used to build OpenJDK, begin by extracting the IcedTea package et changing into the extracted dirctory.

The IcedTea OpenJDK distribuion requires that js.jar (from the Rhino package) be in place in order to provide a java-script implementation for the free JDK. If you have not installed the js.jar file in another way, do so with the following commands as the root user:

As mentioned previously, OpenJDK is composed of several individual projects of the proprietary JDK that have been relicensed under an open source license. Put all of the individual components into the source tree with the following

screen.userinput: cp -v ../corba.tar.gz . && cp -v ../hotspot.tar.gz . && cp -v ../jaxp.tar.gz . && cp -v ../jaxws.tar.gz . && cp -v ../jdk.tar.gz . && cp -v ../langtools.tar.gz . && cp -v ../openjdk.tar.gz .

sect2.para: Apply a patch to generate a valid cacerts file using the system CA certificates:
Apply a patch to replace fixed paths with ones appropriate for BLFS:
Apply a patch to exclude known broken tests from the test suite:
Configure et build the package with the following

Pour tester le résultat, tapez : make jtregcheck. The included version of jtreg is old, et the test suite is also very dependent on the host system et the environment that it is run in. You should expect to see anywhere between a clean set of tests et up to 160 failures in jdk with up to 17 errors in the tests themselves. The majority of the 6000+ tests should pass. The reason for the greatly varrying results is due to how stringent the testing environment must be. Varrying architechtures, different versions of dependent libraries, unexpected X Window environment et window managers, the CA certificates used to generate the cacerts file, et even any user input or power management or screen saver interuptions during the testing can lead to various failures. While the known broken tests have been removed, with the fix_tests patch above, the graphics tests faiulres cannot be pre-determined (short of removing them all). Best bet for a completely clean result is to run the test suite in a frambuffer on a different screen (Xvfb). Even still, Disk I/O can cause failures.
Install the package with the following commands as the root user:

sect2.title: Explications des commandes
sect2.para: ./autogen.sh : This command forces rebuilding of auto-generated files to account for new options added to configure.
--with-jdk-home : This switch provides the location of the temporary JDK.
--enable-nss : This switch enables the build to utilize additional crytography supplied by the nss libraries.
--enable-pulse-audio : This switch enables building of the pulseaudio libraries (needed to provide a complete implementation that is reasonably compatible with the proprietary JDK).

sect3.title: Configuration Information
sect3.para: There are now two OpenJDK SDKs installed in /opt. You should decide on which one you would like to use as the default. For example if you decide to use the precompiled OpenJDK, do the following as the root user:

The information below assumes your system is set up using the instructions found in . You may need to extract the relevant information below et incorporate it into your system's startup files if your system is set up differently.
Add the following openjdk.sh shell startup file to the /etc/profile.d directory with the following commands as the root user:

screen.userinput:
cat > /etc/profile.d/openjdk.sh << "EOF" # Begin /etc/profile.d/openjdk.sh
# Set JAVA_HOME directory JAVA_HOME=/opt/OpenJDK
# Adjust PATH pathappend ${JAVA_HOME}/bin PATH
# Auto Java CLASSPATH # Copy jar files to, or create symlinks in this directory AUTO_CLASSPATH_DIR=/usr/share/java pathprepend . CLASSPATH for dir in `find ${AUTO_CLASSPATH_DIR} -type d 2>/dev/null`; do pathappend $dir CLASSPATH done for jar in `find ${AUTO_CLASSPATH_DIR} -name "*.jar" 2>/dev/null`; do pathappend $jar CLASSPATH done
export JAVA_HOME CLASSPATH unset AUTO_CLASSPATH_DIR unset dir unset jar
# End /etc/profile.d/openjdk.sh EOF

sect3.para: Finally, add the man pages to man_db's configuration. As the root user:

screen.userinput: cat >> /etc/man_db.conf << "EOF" && MANDATORY_MANPATH /opt/OpenJDK/man MANPATH_MAP /opt/OpenJDK/bin /opt/OpenJDK/man MANDB_MAP /opt/OpenJDK/man /var/cache/man/OpenJDK EOF mandb -c /opt/OpenJDK/man

seglistitem.seg: appletviewer, apt, extcheck, idlj, jar, jarsigner, java, javac, javadoc, javah, javap, java-rmi.cgi, jcmd, jconsole, jdb, jhat, jinfo, jmap, jps, jrunscript, jsadebugd, jstack, jstat, jstatd, keytool, native2ascii, orbd, pack200, policytool, rmic, rmid, rmiregistry, schemagen, serialver, servertool, tnameserv, unpack200, wsgen, wsimport, et xjc

listitem.para: allows you to run applets outside of a web browser.
is an annotation processing tool.
checks a specified jar file for title et version conflicts with any extensions installed in the OpenJDK software.
generates Java bindings from a given IDL file.
combines multiple files into a single jar archive.
signs jar files et verifies the signatures et integrity of a signed jar file.
launches a Java application by starting a Java runtime environment, loading a specified class et invoking its main method.
reads class et interface definitions, written in the Java programming language, et compiles them into bytecode class files.
parses the declarations et documentation comments in a set of Java source files et produces a corresponding set of HTML pages describing the classes, interfaces,constructors, methods, et fields.
generates C header et source files that are needed to implement native methods.
disassembles a Java class file.
is the Java RMI client.
is a utility to send diagnostic command requests to a running Java Virtual Machine.
is a graphical console tool to monitor et manage both local et remote Java applications et virtual machines.
is a simple command-line debugger for Java classes.
parses a java heap dump file et allows viewing in a webbrowser.
prints Java configuration information for a given Java process, core file, or a remote debug server.
prints shared object memory maps or heap memory details of a given process, core file, or a remote debug server.
lists the instrumented JVMs on the target system.
is a command line script shell.
attaches to a Java process or core file et acts as a debug server.
prints Java stack traces of Java threads for a given Java process, core file, or a remote debug server.
displays performance statistics for an instrumented JVM.
is an RMI server application that monitors for the creation et termination of instrumented JVMs.
is a key et certificate management utility.
converts files that contain non-supported character encoding into files containing Latin-1 or Unicode-encoded characters.
is used to enable clients to transparently locate et invoke persistent objects on servers in the CORBA environment.
is a Java application that transforms a jar file into a compressed pack200 file using the Java gzip compressor.
creates et manages a policy file graphically.
generates stub et skeleton class files for remote objects from the names of compiled Java classes that contain remote object implementations.
starts the activation system daemon.
creates et starts a remote object registry on the specified port on the current host.
is a Java XML binding schema generator.
returns the serialVersionUID for one or more classes in a form suitable for copying into an evolving class.
provides an ease-of-use interface for application programmers to register, unregister, startup et shutdown a server.
starts the Java IDL name server.
is a native implementation that transforms a packed file produced by pack200 into a jar file.
generates JAX-WS portable artifacts used in JAX-WS web services.
generates JAX-WS portable artifacts.
is a Java XML binding compiler.
